So although I can see many flaws by having to use 10 or 100 exoplanet systems to stitch this history together, I do think it's sort of a unique window in emergence and evolution of life that we um probably don't get any other way unless we can manage to live for a very long time in which case it's not a problem. meeting_annotations.transcript: One thing that we sort of have scratched on a little bit but didn't fully talk about is this question about, you know, our expectations on whether life is going to really take over inhabited worlds or whether it's going to be able to exist at the fringes of inhabited worlds. Um and does that lead to a prioritization of what we should look for or uh I'm not trying to exclude ocean worlds at all. I'm just I'm wondering if there are different in the same way there are different classes of worlds, there may be different classes of biospheres and that may change the the strategy for thinking about commonalities between them.
